message: Analytics: Chartbeat/GoSquared - high level view of what your customers are doing on the site
Non-tech: belief
tech
Configuration management (puppet, chef, cfengine) - Essential, I can't imagine not having this
Monitoring - what is happening with your site on every level (Application, Operating System, Network)
Tests - so you can understand what happens when you change a bit of code
Any more tech/non-tech essentials? :)
Hudson/Jenkins/CI - Something building your code on commit
Status page/Ops communication channel... nothing worse than dealing with a startup/company who look like they don't care when something bad happens.
VM: Generic vm so your developers can get on with coding. You're not coding on your mac when you're deploying to debian, right..? :P

So for a while now I've been collecting some obvious things that you should get in place when doing a startup... mainly from a tech point of view, because I think the main non-tech thing to have in place is belief... belief in what you do and why you do it... and being able to communicate what you believe in. Here's my list
Backups... oh yes, you really need them.
Stalkr setup (what the fuck are your customers breaking and how are they breaking it)
Deployment system - that isn't stupid
@rlofthouse i tried Chartbeat - but prefer GetClicky - just a thought.
@deancollins Nice, I hadn't heard of GetClicky. Will give them a spin.
@rlofthouse Nice list.
Also Geckoboard. Great customizable business analytics dashboard
what do you recommend for config management (ie. puppet vs chef?)
awesome list
@billtrammel I agree, whether it's geckodashboard or your own custom one... it's very useful for the business to have a centralised view of what's happening in all the moving parts of the company.

@liveink whichever works best for you really... I've used puppet primarily but I'm going to give Chef a go. There are subtle differences between the two. Take a clean machine and try installing something simple like apache and one of its modules or whatever you like with puppet, then try doing it with chef and see which one suits you.
@liveink In my case we just happened to be using puppet at work... so I got more familiar with that.
More for the list:
Keep your tech simple. Although it's nice to use everything new under the sun, maintaining it can be a huge nightmare.
Server Density for server monitoring, gives you great insight how your server is and was performing
